§Learn Seneca

Want to learn how to use Seneca to build microservice systems? Enter the Seneca dojo and follow the seven steps to enlightenment.

  • ▰ White Belt: learn the basics.
  • ▰ Orange Belt: get microservices talking to each other.
  • ▰ Green Belt: write some business logic.
  • ▰ Purple Belt: transporting messages and talking to strangers.
  • ▰ Blue Belt: run a minimum viable product with containers.
  • ▰ Red Belt: design and run a full system.
  • ▰ Black Belt: contribute by writing plugins and helping the community.


[⇧]

§▰ White Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Install, run and use Seneca
  • ▰ Use pattern matching to model your business requirements
  • ▰ Use logging to figure out what’s going on
  • ▰ Learn about and use the core plugins

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ Getting started
  • ▰ TODO Using pattern matching
  • ▰ TODO Core plugins

Try this example code:

  • ▰ TODO helloworld
  • ▰ TODO colors
  • ▰ TODO salestax

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ TODO Core API
  • ▰ Core plugins

Blood, sweat, and tears:

(AKA: Don’t worry, this part is supposed to be hard.)

  • ▰ Learning the pattern matching rules and running them “in your head”.
  • ▰ Grokking the log output.


[⇧]

§▰ Orange Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Get microservices talking to each other over the network
  • ▰ Unit test your microservices
  • ▰ Work with databases
  • ▰ Understand Seneca prior actions
  • ▰ Control log output
  • ▰ Submit issues and ask questions

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ Logging
  • ▰ Unit tests
  • ▰ Entities
  • ▰ Understanding priors
  • ▰ TODO The Seneca community

Try this example code:

  • ▰ TODO two-microservices
  • ▰ TODO color-service
  • ▰ TODO salestax-system
  • ▰ TODO basic-data
  • ▰ TODO cmdline

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ Seneca instance
  • ▰ Seneca methods
  • ▰ Seneca utilities
  • ▰ TODO Seneca entities
  • ▰ TODO Seneca command line
  • ▰ Storage plugins

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ Connecting things over the network never works the first time. Invest in understanding the log output to help debug.
  • ▰ Timeouts are annoying.
  • ▰ Prior actions make writing components easy, but you need to understand the rules.
  • ▰ Entities are opinionated, so they might not be what you need. You should still understand them as they are used by many plugins.
  • ▰ The Seneca community and maintainers probably won’t respond in real-time. Sorry.


[⇧]

§▰Green Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Connect your web framework (express, hapi, etc.) to Seneca
  • ▰ Write business logic plugins and expose them as microservices (this is why you’re here!)
  • ▰ Use pins to pattern match the patterns (meta!)
  • ▰ Configure custom logging and integrate with analytics services so you can debug your microservices
  • ▰ Give a meetup talk about Seneca
  • ▰ Configure Seneca

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ Write a plugin
  • ▰ TODO Route messages
  • ▰ TODO Advanced logging
  • ▰ TODO Debugging
  • ▰ TODO Give meetup talks
  • ▰ TODO Configure Seneca

Try this example code:

  • ▰ TODO seneca-express
  • ▰ TODO seneca-hapi
  • ▰ TODO more

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ Seneca messages
  • ▰ Seneca modifiers
  • ▰ Seneca options

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ Getting used to thinking in terms of message flows takes practice.
  • ▰ Finding the right patterns to match your messages takes trial and error.
  • ▰ Reading and interpreting log files is hard.
  • ▰ Live-coding at a meetup is harder than it looks.


[⇧]

§▰Purple Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Use different message transports
  • ▰ Choose the right service discovery mechanism
  • ▰ Use a peer-to-peer service mesh
  • ▰ Draw and generate diagrams to describe your microservices
  • ▰ Write shield plugins to wrap other elements of your network
  • ▰ Understand the standard message flow patterns

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ TODO Message transport
  • ▰ TODO Monitor messages
  • ▰ TODO Service discovery
  • ▰ TODO Service mesh
  • ▰ TODO Shield plugins

Try this example code:

  • ▰ TODO seneca-http
  • ▰ TODO seneca-tcp
  • ▰ TODO seneca-redis
  • ▰ TODO seneca-zeromq
  • ▰ TODO seneca-amqp
  • ▰ TODO seneca-kafka

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ Seneca protocol
  • ▰ Transport plugins

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ Connecting everything end-to-end is not going to work the first time
  • ▰ Mesh networks are powerful, but you need to understand the core concepts


[⇧]

§▰Blue Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Design and build a Minimum Viable Product using microservices
  • ▰ Use containers to run your microservices
  • ▰ Write a blog post about Seneca
  • ▰ Give a conference talk about Seneca
  • ▰ Integrate with microservices written in other languages

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ TODO Containers
  • ▰ TODO Blog post
  • ▰ TODO Conference talk
  • ▰ TODO Polyglot services

Try this example code:

  • ▰ TODO todo list
  • ▰ ramanujan twitter clone

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ TODO cheatsheet

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ Your use of Node.js will be ridiculed
  • ▰ Your use of microservices will be ridiculed
  • ▰ Container networking is designed to make you cry
  • ▰ Integration is hard, always


[⇧]

§▰Red Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Write utility plugins

  • ▰ Design a microservice system

  • ▰ Use orchestration (Kubernetes!)

  • ▰ Write a tutorial

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ TODO System design
  • ▰ TODO System design
  • ▰ TODO Orchestration

Try this example code:

  • ▰ Nodezoo

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ Microservice books

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ You’ll have to leave the Seneca documentation behind, and read the source code directly


[⇧]

§▰Black Belt

Learn how to:

  • ▰ Maintain a Seneca plugin
  • ▰ Contribute to Seneca

Follow these tutorials:

  • ▰ TODO Maintain a plugin
  • ▰ TODO Contribute to Seneca core

Try this example code:

  • ▰ CODE OF CONDUCT

Use this reference material:

  • ▰ roadmap
  • ▰ roadmap

Blood, sweat, and tears:

  • ▰ Joining and participating in a community takes time, patience, and respect.

§Acknowledgment

This learning approach is inspired by Kathy Sierra’s book Badass: Making Users Awesome. You should read it. It will make you awesome.

Issues? From spelling errors to broken tutorials and everything in between, report them here.
